page.title: 18A FARMER'S DAY IN PLYMTREE
page.content: I listen to the 5.30am news, then check the dry cows for calving diffi- culties. The milkers are brought into a collecting yard and their cubicles mechanically scraped & the slurry pushed into a slurry store. The 130 cows are milked in a herringbone 12:12 parlour. Once a month the vet comes to check cows for pregnancy, etc. The 130 replacement heifers are then cleaned out & fed silage. The milkers eat self feed silage and concentrates from com_ puterized feeders. The cubicles are freshly bedded using a motorized straw chopper. The rest of the morning & afternoon could be taken up by de- horning small calves, moving stock & ear-tagging for identification, etc. The routine of scraping out & milking is repeated from 4.30-7.30pm. Before retiring to bed I check the cows one last time.
